abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>We examined the power of detecting linkage heterogeneity when the null hypothesis is that all families are linked to one locus (A) and the two alternative hypotheses are either (1) a proportion of the families are linked to locus A and the remaining families are linked to a second locus B or (2) a proportion of the families are linked to locus A or B and a third proportion of the families are unlinked to either locus. The power of detecting linkage heterogeneity is estimated for various proportions of families linked to loci A, B or unlinked to either locus (sampling under the alternative hypothesis). To estimate the significance level, the data set is sampled under the null hypothesis. For sampling under both hypotheses, a bootstrap approach is employed, sampling the simulated pedigrees with replacement.</jats:p><jats:p>The power to detect linkage heterogeneity is strongest when the recombination fraction is 0 and equal proportions of the families are linked to loci A and B. The power decreases as the recombination fraction increases, the propor‐tion of unlinked families increases and the disparity between the proportion of the families linked to either locus A or B increases. In the data set of 32 Duke Familial Alzheimer Disease families, when equal proportions of families are linked to loci A and B, the power to detect linkage heterogeneity is 0.94 using a likelihood ratio criterion of 10:1. The p value that corresponds to the likelihood ratio of 1O:l is estimated as 0.013 with a 95% confidence interval for p ranging from 0.012 to 0.014. © 1993 Wiley‐Liss, Inc.</jats:p>
